description: APS Peak Solutions is a commercial and industrial demand response program operated by Arizona Public Service (APS) in partnership with CPower Energy. Launched in 2010, the program provides financial rewards to business customers who voluntarily reduce electricity consumption during peak demand periods, typically during summer months (June-September). The program has notably low barriers to entry with a minimum 10 kW commitment and no penalties for non-performance, making it accessible to both small and large commercial customers. A program redesign is planned for Fall 2025.

service_territories: APS service territory covering Phoenix metropolitan area and surrounding regions
geography.notes: APS is Arizona's largest utility serving approximately 2.7 million people

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Program is designed to include both small and large commercial/industrial organizations. Minimum 10 kW load commitment is significantly lower than typical 50 kW minimum for most US commercial DR programs.

eligibility.notes: CPower manages program enrollment, facility assessments, measurement, verification, and payment distribution on behalf of APS. Customers can enroll at cpowerenergy.com/aps or call 844-276-9371.

notification_methods: not specified - likely email, SMS, phone
notification.notification_notes: Day Ahead notification option available where participants are notified by noon the day before an event. Specific notification methods not detailed in public documentation but likely include standard digital notification channels.

capacity_rate.notes: Program provides capacity payments but specific rates are not publicly disclosed. Payment structure appears to be customized per participant. Initial program scrape suggested rates but these could not be verified from authoritative sources.

performance_rate.notes: Program provides performance payments for energy reduced during events. Specific rates not publicly disclosed. Payment appears customized based on facility assessment and enrolled capacity.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: No penalties for non-performance. This is explicitly highlighted as a key program feature to attract first-time demand response participants.

payment_structure.payment_notes: Customers can earn 'between hundreds and hundreds of thousands of dollars' depending on enrolled capacity and performance. In 2023 program season, participants collectively earned more than $870,000. Royal Paper earned nearly $85,000 for participation in summer 2023. Payments appear to be a combination of capacity payments for enrollment and performance payments for actual curtailment during events.

seasons.notes: Program operates primarily June through September when Arizona experiences extreme heat and peak electricity demand. Events called during highest usage periods, typically 4-7 PM.

call_windows.notes: APS customers typically use the most power between 4 PM and 7 PM, particularly during summer months. This is the primary call window for Peak Solutions events. Note: Arizona does not observe Daylight Saving Time.

event_parameters.notes: Specific event parameters not disclosed in public documentation. Events are called during periods of exceptionally high demand, typically during extreme summer heat.

event_triggers.trigger_description: Events are called during periods of exceptionally high electricity demand on the APS grid, typically during extreme summer heat when temperatures exceed 110°F. The program helps APS maintain grid reliability and avoid outages during peak demand periods. Events are called when customer energy use creates grid stress.
event_triggers.examples: Phoenix experienced 55 days above 110°F in summer 2023 (hottest summer on record). August 4, 2024: APS customers set all-time peak demand record at 8,210 MW. These extreme heat events trigger Peak Solutions calls.

nomination_bidding.notes: Enrollment appears to be ongoing through CPower. Customers receive personalized facility assessment and conservation plan upon enrollment. Load reduction strategies remain at customer discretion - voluntary participation in each event.

research_notes: Conducted comprehensive web research on APS Peak Solutions program on 2025-10-11. Research included APS official sources, CPower partner sources, press releases, and web searches for regulatory filings. Program is well-documented for high-level features (eligibility, launch date, partnership structure, no penalties) but specific operational and financial details are not publicly available. The 10 kW minimum and no-penalty structure are consistently highlighted across sources as differentiators. Payment structure appears to be customized per participant rather than published fixed rates. Found good earnings examples (2023 collective $870K, Royal Paper $85K) but not underlying rate structures. Program appears to operate primarily June-September during Arizona's extreme summer heat, with peak hours 4-7 PM. Arizona does not observe Daylight Saving Time. Program is part of larger APS Virtual Power Plant initiative approaching 200 MW total capacity. Fall 2025 redesign mentioned but details not available. For complete operational parameters and financial details, direct enrollment or contact with CPower (844-276-9371) would be required. Overall data quality is moderate - good program description and eligibility details, but missing critical operational and payment specifics that would be needed for optimization modeling.

integration_metadata.notes: Program is mature (14+ years), actively operating, and part of APS's strategic clean energy initiatives. The low 10 kW minimum and no-penalty structure make it accessible for smaller commercial customers and first-time DR participants. Payment structures appear customized based on facility assessment rather than published fixed rates. Good candidate for battery or flexible load optimization given summer-focused operation, predictable peak hours (4-7 PM), and day-ahead notification option. However, lack of published event limits (max events/hours per year) makes revenue forecasting challenging without direct program enrollment. Program redesign planned for Fall 2025 may bring changes to structure and potentially better public documentation.
